huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
The Book Cliffs antelope population has been steadily declining since 1998.  It could be from a combination of drought, predation, and interspecific competition.  It is a still a good place to draw a permit.  It is such a large area that hunter competition is really low.  I would put a significant effort into pre-season scouting on this unit.  Don’t be afraid to ask the oil field workers where they have been seeing pronghorn.  They drive the roads that go right through prime antelope habitat every day and can be a great resource.  

I would work on locating water sources.  Unless it rains which has been a rare occurrence, antelope have to come to water.  It is an extremely fun hunt, and you can see antelope all throughout the day.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

The Book Cliffs mountain range is one of the more remote areas in Utah.  There are no service stations for many miles.  Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, good tires with extra spares, and plenty of ice.

The Book Cliffs has a high bear population. Keep a clean camp and put your garbage in a place that is inaccessible to bears.  If you do have problems with bears please report them to the DWR Northeastern Regional Office as soon as possible (435 781-9453), or call the local dispatch center (435 789-4222).
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, and hot conditions.  Storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~600~300~~~2.0–3.0~4.3~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.CLASSIFICATION_DATA: Post season buck to doe ratio in 2014, 13 bucks/100 does
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest:  The majority of hunters choose to hunt close to the Seep Ridge Road on the north end of the unit.  After the road crosses the White River you are on the unit.  Once you cross the river and are off of Tribal land I would start focusing your efforts there.  There are several wide open flats with folding hills that antelope prefer.   The Glen Bench Road is the first major road that takes you back to the east.  I wouldn’t be deterred from all of the oil field traffic.  The oil field workers spend a lot of time driving through prime antelope habitat, and can provide some great scouting tips.  

On the west side of the unit there is a large open area called Wild Horse Bench.  It is a popular place for antelope, elk, wild horses, livestock, and some deer.  I have seen antelope in this area, but it is a large area and sometimes they are difficult to locate.  I don’t think it receives very much hunting pressure.  

Winter Ridge is an area with sparse antelope, but receives very little hunting pressure.  

Migration Patterns:  The Book Cliffs antelope herd does not show many signs of migration.  Throughout the year they stay in the same general area.  During the rut the larger herds tend to break up into smaller herds with one to two bucks in the herd.  The great thing about hunting antelope is that you can hunt them all throughout the day.  

Vegetative communities that dominate the areas of the herd unit frequented by pronghorn include salt desert shrub types on the lower elevation zones grading upward in elevation to Wyoming sage habitats.  Annual precipitation generally varies from 6 to 8 inches in these vegetation types.  Forb production is important for healthy fawn survival.  Water distribution can be limiting but has been provided by the BLM and other conservation interests through guzzlers or other devices.  During the past decade of drought, the poor maintenance condition of many of these artificial water sources limited their effectiveness.  Repairs have been made and are continuing.  

Natural gas and oil production is rapidly increasing on pronghorn range with subsequent vegetative removal limiting both forage availability and habitat effectiveness.  Habitat loss and disturbance associated with drilling and other energy extraction activities may be a significant factor affecting pronghorn populations.  I have seen antelope shade up during the day under the large tanks on oil well pads.  

Scouting Tips:
A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential.  Scouting is most effective right before the hunt opens.  I would plan on covering a lot of ground to locate springs and guzzlers in the more arid areas on the northern part of the unit.  Trail cameras can make a big difference in scouting these areas.  Once you locate a buck there is a good chance he will stay in same vicinity.   

Behavior:  Antelope are fairly solitary, and herd up in small groups during the rut.  Bucks like to make scrapes in the dirt roads to make territories and warn off other competing bucks.  I don’t see large herds of antelope on this unit.  A large group of antelope in the Book Cliffs is 12-18 head.  They have to stay relatively close to a sustainable water source.  If it rains they are less likely to visit springs or guzzlers and more likely to drink out of hoof prints or natural water catches.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: The majority of land is managed by the BLM.  There is a significant amount of SITLA land.  There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA).  These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas.  There is private land and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program (http://wildlife.utah.gov/walkinaccess/).
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, and Willow Creek WMAs.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html)
BLM:  14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days.
DWR WMA’S:  UDWR WMAs is limited to 14 days at one location.  On the Willow Creek WMA, camping is not allowed.  In the parcels that can be accessed by county roads there is no camping allowed.  Camping is only allowed in the parcels where the roads are closed, like Meadow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: Seep Ridge Road (UT 88) and the Bonanza Highway/Atchee Ridge Road (UT 45) from the North, Hay Canyon from I-70 on the South
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office, and SITLA.  The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.   

Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.  

The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape.  There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them.  Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access.  There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads.  The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.  

There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs.  The Kings Well Rd starts at the Seep Ridge Rd on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Rd on the east side.  The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Rd and goes through the bottom of Sweet Water, top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek, and to Big Park
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands.  There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit.  Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads.  All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.  

There are some private ranches that post their property.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at the Utah-Colorado state line and the White River; south along this state line to the Book Cliffs summit (north-south drainage divide); west along this summit and drainage divide to Ten Mile Knoll and the Steer Ridge road; north and west along the Steer Ridge road (atop the drainage divide) to the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation Boundary (NW 1/4 Sec 7, T17S R21E); north along this boundary to the Uintah-Grand county line; west along this county line to the Green River; north along this river to the White River; east along this river to the Utah-Colorado state line. EXCLUDING ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Vernal, Price, Westwater, Seep Ridge. Boundary questions? Call the Vernal Office, 435-781-9453.
